  sgcool_label_text: The long robe (known as ‘changshan’in Southern China and Hong Kong and ‘changpao’  in Northern China) was the standard informal garment worn by men during the early Republican period in China and Hong Kong. It is a one-piece long robe that can be worn alone or under a short jacket known as a ‘magua’ . This robe was tailored at a certain tailor shop by the name of Lu Xin Long   in Hong Kong.\r\n\r\nThis exquisite robe belonged to Mr Kaan Tat Choi
 who was a successful businessman in the bullion business in Hong Kong. Mr Kaan expanded his business to Malaya in the 1920s
 acquiring several rubber plantations along the east coast of Malaya. He also opened a bullion trading company called “Yee Shing” at 20 Canal Road in Singapore in the 1930s. \r\n

metadata.title_text: Men’s light blue silk long robe (Changshan)
metadata.physical_appearance: This is a blue silk robe that is buttoned on the proper right. The sleeves are broad, and the robes are decorated with curvilinear and linear forms.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Silk Ethnic costume Men's clothing Robes
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
The long robe (known as ‘changshan’in Southern China and Hong Kong and ‘changpao’  in Northern China) was the standard informal garment worn by men during the early Republican period in China and Hong Kong. It is a one-piece long robe that can be worn alone or under a short jacket known as a ‘magua’ . This robe was tailored at a certain tailor shop by the name of Lu Xin Long   in Hong Kong.

This exquisite robe belonged to Mr Kaan Tat Choi, who was a successful businessman in the bullion business in Hong Kong. Mr Kaan expanded his business to Malaya in the 1920s, acquiring several rubber plantations along the east coast of Malaya. He also opened a bullion trading company called “Yee Shing” at 20 Canal Road in Singapore in the 1930s.
